task.title: Adding storage to an existing thin pool

taskbody.prereq: To perform this procedure, you need at least one unused primary partition on the target host.
taskbody.context: Perform this procedure to add unused space to an existing device mapper thin pool.

step.cmd: Log in to the target host .
Identify the primary partition or partitions to add to a thin pool, and record the total size.

substep.cmd: Display information about block devices on the host.

stepxmp.p: For more information about the output of the lsblk command, see .

substep.cmd: Record the total size of the primary partion or partitions to add.
substep.info: The total size is required for the last step.

step.cmd: Create a physical volume on each target primary partition, if necessary.
step.info: Repeat the following substeps for each primary partition to include in the volume group for the target thin pool.

substep.cmd: Determine whether a physical volume is present.
substep.stepxmp:
Replace Device with the path of a primary partition:
Ubuntu hosts: sudo pvs Device RHEL/CentOS hosts: pvs Device
Replace Device with the path of a primary partition: pvs Device
substep.stepresult: If the result includes Failed to find physical volume, perform the next substep.

substep.stepxmp:
Replace Device with the path of a primary partition:
Ubuntu hosts: sudo pvcreate Device RHEL/CentOS hosts: pvcreate Device
pvcreate Device
Replace Device with the path of a primary partition: pvcreate Device

step.cmd: Extend the volume group of the target thin pool.
step.stepxmp:
To extend the volume group of the Docker thin pool, enter one of the following commands. Replace PhysicalVolumes with the names of one or more physical volumes:
Ubuntu hosts: sudo vgextend docker PhysicalVolumes RHEL/CentOS hosts: vgextend docker PhysicalVolumes

To extend the volume group of the thin pool, enter one of the following commands. Replace PhysicalVolumes with the names of one or more physical volumes:
Ubuntu hosts: sudo vgextend serviced PhysicalVolumes RHEL/CentOS hosts: vgextend serviced PhysicalVolumes
To extend the volume group of the Docker thin pool, enter the following command. Replace PhysicalVolumes with the names of one or more physical volumes: vgextend docker PhysicalVolumes
To extend the volume group of the thin pool, enter the following command. Replace PhysicalVolumes with the names of one or more physical volumes: vgextend serviced PhysicalVolumes

step.cmd: Extend the target thin pool with the updated volume group.
step.stepxmp:
To extend the Docker thin pool, enter one of the following commands. Replace SIZE with the total size (including the units) of the physical volumes that you added to the docker volume group:
Ubuntu hosts: sudo lvextend -L+SIZE docker/dockerpool RHEL/CentOS hosts: lvextend -L+SIZE docker/dockerpool

To extend the thin pool, enter one of the following commands. Replace SIZE with the total size (including the units) of the physical volumes that you added to the serviced volume group:
Ubuntu hosts: sudo lvextend -L+SIZE serviced/servicedpool RHEL/CentOS hosts: lvextend -L+SIZE serviced/servicedpool

To extend the Docker thin pool, enter the following command. Replace SIZE with the total size (including the units) of the physical volumes that you added to the docker volume group: lvextend -L+SIZE docker/docker-pool

To extend the thin pool, enter the following command. Replace SIZE with the total size (including the units) of the physical volumes that you added to the serviced volume group: lvextend -L+SIZE serviced/serviced-pool
step.stepresult: The lvextend command automatically extends both the data and metadata areas of the thin pool.
